column1: 178;Portugal;PTLISBOA01-1 - Universidade Católica Portuguesa - Lisboa;2017/2018;Fakultät für Betriebswirtschaftslehre - BWL;Management (MMM)
column2: Master - BWL_M_BWL;264882;"The application process for my semester abroad was really clear and straightforward.

column1: I received a positive answer about my application as outgoing student in December 2016 and I was contacted by the host institution several months before the semester started.
I have received my credentials for the University Portal of the host institution by email and I have been constantly updtated about the required tasks for incoming students.
The week before the courses started
column2: the University organized a welcome week for all the international students; this was the opportunity to both discover more about the University and its surrounding environment (including sport activities
column3: students' organizations within the University
column4: etc) and to deliver the necessary papers (certificate of arrival and learning agreement) to the International Office.

column1: We have been welcomed in a truly fantastic way by both the International Office and the students' associations
column2: especially by Erasmus Life Lisboa
column3: which organized many actitivities during the Welcome Week.";"I have found an accomodation through the housing department of Erasmus Life Lisboa. They gave me a fantastic support in choosing the right place for me.

column1: I have contacted the reposnsible person directly on Facebook and she provided me with all the information about the characteristics of the different areas of the city
column2: so that I could find the proper place depending on my needs.

column1: During the Welcome Week also other organizations came to the University to support students in case they did not find an accomodation yet.
The University does not provide accomodation directly but there are many associations succesfully helping with that (Erasmus Life Lisboa
column2: Uniplaces
column3: etc.).

column1: I lived in Bairro Alto
column2: which is the most frequented nightlife area in Lisbon. It is a very turistic area and there always many people around during the night.

column1: I do not reccomend it if someone wants to avoid noise during the night
column2: however it is perfrctly located to reach many part of the city by foot.

column1: I only took the metro to go to the University
column2: which is not in the city centre. The closest stop from my house was five minutes by foot and I could get directly to the closest University stop
column3: which was ten minutes walking from the University.

column1: There are many small grocery shops in the area of Bairro Alto and one supermarket (Minipreco) five minutes distant by foot.";"The International Office of the Host Institution provided me in advance a very clear catalogue with all the courses offered and their respective syllabus.
This was really helpful to understand more in depth the topic of the class and what type of exam we had to expect.
The offer of the courses included all the areas of the Business and Economics field (finance
column2: management
column3: marketing
column4: economics
column5: etc).

column1: The semester is divided into two trimesters and courses are offered both during the single trimesters (the majority) and during the whole semester.
The educational approach at Catolica School of Business and Economics focuses on business cases
column2: so it aims to provide skills to students through the analysis of real- life experieces.

column1: Every class is composed by not more than 30/35 students and every lecure has a section dedicated to the analysis of the business cases that were assigned as homework.
In all the courses participation was graded
column2: with a percentage of the final grade that ranged from 5% until 20%.

column1: Moreover
column2: all the courses included at least a group presentation or a group project to be done during the course period (with an average percentage of the final grade of 40%).

column1: I have found this practical approach very useful to develop my knowledge in the business field and I really appreciated the opportunity to constantly confront with the Professors during the lectures.
The University has a canteen (open only during lunch) and a bar (open the whole day) that offer a very good service.
There is a library where everyone have to keep silence and many study areas where students can do their group projects.
There are also many computer rooms where it is also possible to print with your student account.
The University is open 24 hours every day of the week.

I did not take any portugues language course but both the University and the various students' organizations offered language courses at convenient prices.";"I have arrived in Lisbon one month before the courses started to get to know the city and the local lifestyle.
I have found portuguese people very friendly and open. The main business in the city is tourism so many locals are used to get in touch with international people (in terms of language
column2: culures and general approach).

column1: The weather is one of the most beautiful in Europe
column2: I have experienced almost only sunny days and warm temperatures
column3: even in December.

column1: Lisbon is always full of events of any type
column2: is the cultural centre of the country and in the last years has been constantly attracting more and more tourists. The main concept of the nightlife is to gather together with other people outside
column3: because the great weather conditions allow you to stay outside most of the time
column4: rather than in the bars.

column1: Especially in the area around Bairro Alto there are plenty of places where to meet new people every day (bars
column2: parks
column3: viewpoints where many people gather together).

column1: The city looks beautiful and it has a long past of history that can be experienced through the many walking tours also offered by students' organizations and visiting the numerous museums.
There is a direct connection from the city centre (Cais do Sodrè railway station) to the beach
column2: that can be reach in twenty minutes.

column1: Lisbon is perfectly located for traveling both to the north of the coutry and the south
column2: where there are beautiful rural areas in the region of Algarve.

column1: The best way to visit and learn about the history of the city and its local vibe is to walk through all the part of the city
column2: while the best way to travel to the south of the country is to rent a car
column3: which is relatively cheap.";"The price for an accomodation are constantly and rapidly increasing in Lisbon. I paid 300€ per month for my room in a shared flat (with other five people) in Bairro Alto.

column1: This was the average price for an accomodation in the city centre or close to it; however
column2: I have heard of many people paying much more for their room (up to 450€ per month).

column1: The transportation card (valid within the city) costs 36€ per month
column2: while moving by train to go to the surrounding beach is relatively cheap (around 4€ two ways).

column1: Supermarkets are as expensive as the ones in Mannheim while eating in restaurants is cheaper (even though the prices are raising fast because of tourism).
Having a quick snack and drinking something in a bar is definitely cheaper than in Mannheim (the average price for espresso coffee is 0.60€).
A complete meal at the canteen at the University costs as much as at the University of Mannheim.
The cost of travelling within the country by bus is comparable to a low cost company in Germany (e.g. Flixbus)
column2: while the cost of train transportation is cheaper than Germany.

column1: Hovewer
column2: the more convenient way to travel to the other parts of Portugal (even around Lisbon) is to rent a car.

column1: In general
column2: I would say a person need the same monthly budget as in Mannheim. Hovewer
column3: because of the huge offer of leisure acrivities and the rapid increase of prices due to tourism
column4: I would reccomend to consider a slightly higher amount.";"I was interested in working as student assistant at the University but the University did not offer such possibility.

column1: Then I have looked for a part time working position at a company
column2: but they did not offer any monetary benefits.

column1: Finally
column2: I have worked for a small period in a local restaurant.

column1: From my experience I have realized there is a huge gap in the working conditions between Germany and Portugal
column2: especially for students.

column1: As a positive aspect for international people
column2: the huge increase of tourims has opened many job opportunities for people who does not speak the local language.";"Course title: BRAND MANAGEMENT

column1: Course content:
The purpose of this course is to teach you how to build
column2: manage
column3: and leverage world‐class brands. The broad learning of this course are: 1) to increase your understanding of the important issues in planning and evaluating brand strategies; 2) to present relevant theories
column4: conceptual models
column5: and other tools and principles to make more effective branding decisions; and 3) to provide a forum for you to apply these principles. Particular emphasis is placed in the course on understanding psychological principles at the consumer level that will improve managerial decision‐making with respect to brands. Another aim of the course is to make these concepts relevant for any type of organization (public or private
column6: large or small
column7: etc.) Throughout the class we will cover qualitative and quantitative research methods necessary for managing brands.

column1: ECTS: 3
Language: english
Course title: DIGITAL MARKETING
Course content:
The internet
column2: social media and technology have transformed marketing. Customers have gained power
column3: have wider choices and are more informed than ever. On the other hand
column4: the technological platforms have boomed and continue to grow. Due to these changes it has become mandatory for companies to adapt and become adopters of tools that consumers have already integrated in their daily lives.  This course helps navigate new ways that companies can communicate
column5: gain awareness and engage consumers. At the same
column6: digital media can lead to new opportunities
column7: changes in business models and market competiitiveness. These issues will be addressed throughout the course.

column1: english
MANAGING ORGANIZATIONS
The main objective of this course is to help students understand several core topics relating to organizational dynamics such as organizational structure
column2: culture
column3: learning
column4: communication
column5: and change. Through cases
column6: class activities
column7: lectures
column8: and assignments
column9: the course will engage students to reflect and apply organizational behavior concepts
column10: theories
column11: and practices to a variety of real-life organizational settings. By the end of this course
column12: students should be able to develop solutions to a range of organizational issues and recommend strategies to improve organizational effectiveness.

column1: ECTS: 3
Language: english
Course title: INTERNATIONAL MARKETING
Course content:
This course introduces the field of international marketing. It covers the complex and interesting environment of international marketing and its various dimensions such as cultural
column2: economical
column3: political. It then considers how these dimensions interact with marketing elements (e.g.
column4: branding
column5: pricing
column6: channels and distribution
column7: communications
column8: sales promotions
column9: segmentation
column10: targeting
column11: and positioning) and how marketing managers could use them to obtain benefits for the firm and for society as a whole.

column1: ECTS: 3
Language: english
Course title: MANAGERIAL DECISION MAKING
Course content:
This course is designed to provide you with a better understanding about how you and other people think
column2: feel
column3: decide
column4: and behave. One main objective is to increase awareness of the psychological processes that underlie the choices that people make
column5: as well as systematic biases and heuristics that people have when making decisions. A second main objective is to give you a space to reflect on who you are and who you want and do not want to be
column6: as well as provide tools for how to mindfully create a life that aligns with your goals. A third main objective is to better understand how to interact with oneself and other people in ways that are responsible
column7: productive
column8: and mutually rewarding. A last main objective is to appreciate the role of emotions and moods in how people decide and behave. All of these topics will be presented based on scientific research
column9: including related interventions or “brain hacks” which can help people become more effective.

column1: Die Planung des Auslandsemesters beginnt mit der Auswahl der Zieluniversitäten und der Angabe der Prioritäten beim akademischen Auslandsamt an der Uni Mannheim. Erhält man die Zusage für die GSOM
column2: kann die Planung beginnen.

column1: Der wichtigste Schritt der Planung ist das russische Studentenvisum zu beantragen. Für dieses benötigt man:
- einen Reisepass
- Passfotos
- Nachweis über eine Auslandskrankenversicherung
- Einladung der Russischen Universität
- ggf. HIV-Test
Der Reisepass muss über die Dauer des Auslandsemesters hinaus gültig sein. Der Nachweis über die Auslandkrankenversicherung muss explizit ausdrücken
column2: dass dieser den Anforderungen der russischen Botschaft entspricht. Bei meiner Versicherungsgesellschaft habe ich eine extra Bescheinigung hierfür bekommen.

column1: Die konsularische Einladung erhält die Uni Mannheim per Post und wird im Original benötigt. Ich erhielt sie relativ früh und konnte somit mein Visum zeitlich beantragen. Bei anderen Exchangers (auch von anderen deutschen Universitäten) dauerte die Übersendung dieser Einladung sehr lange und manche verpassten sogar die ersten Tage/erste Woche
column2: da sie die Einladung so spät erhielten.

column1: Hat man alle Dokumente beisammen
column2: so kann man das Visum entweder in einer Botschaft/Konsulat beantragen oder einen VHS (Visa Handling Service) damit beauftragen. Diese VHS-Geschäftsstellen befinden sich meist direkt neben den russischen Botschaften Auf ihrer Webseite empfehlt die russische Botschaft den VHS in Anspruch zu nehmen. Die Antragstellung verlief reibungslos jedoch kostete der Service ca. 120
column3: - € obwohl das Visum laut Welcome Guide der GSOM kostenfrei hätte sein sollen. Bei dem Visum ist es wichtig darauf zu achten
column4: dass es für Lernzwecke ausgestellt wird. Auch beantragt man das Visum zunächst für 90 Tage und beantragt dann vor Ort ein weiteres
column5: indem man seinen Reisepass bei der Uni abgibt und offiziell vier Wochen auf das neue Visum wartet. Während dieser Zeit darf man St. Petersburg nicht verlassen und kann daher nicht reisen. Auch nicht nach Moskau. Bei mir (und den anderen Austauschstudierenden) wurde die Vierwochenfrist um weitere sechs Wochen verlängert. Wenn man Reisen plant
column6: kann man den Reisepass auch erst später abgeben und hoffen
column7: ihn zeitgleich mit allen anderen zurückzubekommen.

column1: Ein HIV-Test wurde von manchen bei der Beantragung des Visums verlangt
column2: von mir jedoch nicht. Dies scheint sehr stark zwischen den Botschaften/VHS-Zentren zu variieren. Ich beantrage mein Visum in München und musste ihn nicht einreichen. Andere Deutsche mussten es aber.

column2: kann man einen Flug buchen. Einen Kursplan kann man sich bereits vorher zusammenstellen und Mannheimer Lehrstühle bezüglich Learning Agreements kontaktieren (siehe Besuchte Kurse).

column5: - € pro Person und Monat. Man bekommt ein Bett in einem Dreibettzimmer und kann sich seine Mitbewohner nicht aussuchen. Normalerweise sind diese aber auch Austauschstudierende.

column1: Viele sind in Kaptianskaya geblieben und haben keinen Grund gesehen in die Innenstadt zu ziehen. Sie mochten das russische Flair des Wohnheims und fanden den Preis zu attraktiv um umzuziehen. Es gibt dort pro Etage eine Gemeinschaftsküche und ein Gemeinschaftsbad. Beides liegt deutlich unter europäischen Standards ist aber vollkommen ausreichend für vier bis fünf Monate. Die Betten sind für große Personen (>1
column2: 90m) zu klein und nicht wirklich komfortabel. W-LAN kann man über einen externen Anbieter auf sein Zimmer beziehen.

Hier bietet sich der Stadtteil rund um den Nevsky-Prospekt an. Der Nevsky-Prospekt ist die größte und zentralste Straße St. Petersburgs und man kann von hier aus alles fußläufig erreichen. Eine besonders gefragte Straße war die Rubinsteyna-Street
column4: da es dort sehr viele gute Restaurants und Bars gibt und die Rubinsteyna mittig den Nevsky-Prospekt kreuzt.

column1: Eine solche Wohnung zu finden ist nicht unbedingt einfach aber die russischen Buddies helfen da gerne weiter und kennen über die Zeit auch einige Wohnungen die sozusagen schon immer in ""Exchanger-Hand"" waren und von Generation an Generation weitergegeben werden.

Von der Innenstadt gelangt man innerhalb von ca. 30 Minuten an die Uni. Mit der Metro ein wenig schneller jedoch ist die Metrostation nicht so nahe an der Uni wie die Busstation.";"Die Graduate School of Management besteht seit 1993 und ist eine international anerkannte Business School
column2: welche in vielen internationalen Rankings mitunter hohe Platzierungen erzielt (bspw. Financial Times Ranking 2017: 23. Platz). Insgesamt studieren in etwa 1.200 Studierende in 3 Bachelor und 5 Master Studiengängen. Die Business School hat zwei getrennte Studienorte
column3: welche sich an unterschiedlichen Orten in St. Petersburg befinden (Distanz mindestens eine Stunde). Der Bachelorcampus „Michailovskaya Dacha“ befindet sich im Südwesten der Stadt in der Nähe von Peterhof. Der Mastercampus im „Arthur Schultz Gebäude“ befindet sich hingegen im Herzen der Stadt im südlichen Teil der Vasilyevsky Insel. Durch diese Trennung hatte ich im Grunde ausschließlich Kontakt zu Masterstudierenden
column4: da die enorme Distanz Interaktionen mit Bachelorstudierenden fast unmöglich macht. In beiden Gebäuden gibt es großzügige Lehrräume und modernes Equipment. Darüber hinaus bieten beide Standorte eine eigene Bibliothek an. Gerüchten zufolge plant die Uni beide Gruppen zusammenzulegen und in einer paar Jahren alle Studierenden in der Dacha zu unterrichten. Dies würde die gesamte Logistik des Auslandsemesters ändern und dieser Bericht wäre in den Punkten Unterkunft und Kosten nicht mehr aussagekräftig
column5: da sich das Leben an beiden Standorten sehr unterscheidet.

column1: In beiden Gebäuden der Graduate School befinden sich modernisierte Vorlesungssäle und Unterrichtsräume

column3: es gibt flächendeckendes WLAN und moderne Smartboards. Viele der Räume können auch von den Studenten für individuelle Gruppenarbeiten reserviert werden. Darüber hinaus befindet sich in jedem Gebäude eine Kantine bzw. ein Café. In der Regel findet man hier jederzeit einen Platz und das Essen ist entsprechend günstig. Dennoch bietet es sich

column7: gut und nah). Wer darüber hinaus einen Computer benötigt findet jederzeit Computerräume und PC’s in den Bibliotheken.

column1: Neben den alltäglichen Herausforderungen spielt sich vieles an der Universität ab. Allerdings ist das Campusleben an der GSOM tendenziell kaum vorhanden. Durch die Trennung der Bachelor und Masterstudierenden kann man ohnehin mit vergleichsweise wenigen Personen in Kontakt treten. Studentische Initiativen sind hier kaum vorhanden und auch sonst gibt es wenig Möglichkeiten sich auszutauschen. Die einzig guten Arbeitsplätze am Mastercampus befinden sich in der Bibliothek wo kein Platz für Gespräche und Gruppenarbeiten ist. Den meisten Kontakt mit anderen Studierenden hat man in den Kursen oder innerhalb der Peer-Groups die man in der Einführungswoche kennenlernt. Man sollte auch deshalb an ebendieser Woche teilnehmen
column2: da weitere Kontaktmöglichkeiten danach rar sind.

column1: Dagegen bietet Sankt Petersburg unzählige Möglichkeiten der Freizeitgestaltung. Neben Sportanlagen und Fitnessstudios gibt es auch einige Parks und Trainingsanlagen in der Innenstadt. Für Sport muss man sich also lediglich die Zeit nehmen. An der SPbU und speziell an der GSOM gibt es unzählige Möglichkeiten sich sportlich

column1: Finanziert habe ich mein Auslandstudium über das Auslandsbafög und das Go-EAST-Stipendium des DAAD.";Finanziert habe ich mein Auslandstudium über das Auslandsbafög und das Go-EAST-Stipendium des DAAD.;"Zu Beginn der ersten Semesterwoche (meistens Anfang September) beginnt die Einführungswoche an der GSOM. Grundsätzlich wird an der GSOM anders gelehrt als an der Uni Mannheim. Die Kurse bestehen zu großen Teilen aus Assignments und Präsentationen. Ist man zu den jeweiligen Terminen nicht anwesend bekommt man keine Möglichkeit die Punkte anders zu sammeln. Selbiges gilt für Supply Chain Management und Internationalization of EMNE'S.";Alles in allem habe ich das Auslandssemester in St. Petersburg sehr genossen und auch eine Menge gelernt. column1: Die Zusage für den Austauschplatz erhielt ich gegen Ende der Klausurenphase im Dezember. Die Bestätigung der Uni Göteborg folgte dann im Frühjahr

column5: da keine freien Plätze mehr an Austauschstudierende vergeben werden konnten. Diese Info erhielt ich relativ spät von der Uni Göteborg. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt standen dann nur drei Kurse als Alternative im selben Zeitraum zur Verfügung die mir thematisch eher nicht zugesagt haben.

column7: warum ich mich an der Universität Göteborg beworben habe. Am Ende musste ich aber auch hier einige Abstriche machen
column8: da man für jedes Quartal des Semesters einen Kurs besuchen muss und sich interessante Kurse daher auch gegenseitig ausschließen können. Der Semesteraufbau ist nicht wirklich mit dem von deutschen Unis vergleichbar. Die Kurse an schwedischen Universitäten erstrecken sich über ein oder zwei Quartale des schwedischen Semesters und haben in diesem Zeitraum 50% bzw. 100% Workload. Die meisten Kurse sind 100%-Kurse. Dies bedeutet
column9: dass man sich in der Regel zu einem bestimmten Zeitpunkt mit nur einem Kurs gleichzeitig beschäftigt. Ein Vorteil der 100%-Kurse gegenüber den 50%-Kursen ist
column10: dass man sich das Studium für das Auslandssemester deutlich leichter zusammenstellen kann und flexibler ist als mit 50%-Kursen. Es ist auch möglich in einem Quartal z.B. 150 oder 200% zu belegen
column11: was ich aufgrund des hohen Arbeitsaufwands allerdings nicht empfehlen würde. Ein Quartal erstreckt sich über etwa einen Monat (1. September
column12: 2. Oktober
column13: 3. November und 4. Dezember (evtl. bis Mitte Januar) im Herbstsemester).

column1: Die Kurse in Schweden sind darüber hinaus viel mehr auf Gruppenarbeiten und Präsentationen ausgerichtet

column3: Paper
column4: Case Study) und schließt danach mit einer Klausur oder größeren Eigenleistung ab. In vielen Kursen fließen die Gruppenarbeiten auch in die Endnote ein. Man verbringt relativ viel Zeit mit den Gruppenarbeiten
column5: dafür habe ich die Präsenzzeit in Vorlesungen und Seminaren als relativ gering empfunden. Zudem muss auch viel Literatur für Klausuren und Seminare gelesen werden.

Manche Lehrstühle haben jedoch eine längere Bearbeitungsdauer weswegen man sich möglichst früh um die Anrechnung kümmern sollte. Gerade ab November wird es dann jedoch auch früh dunkel und es regnet häufig. Kurze Hosen waren während des Herbstsemesters leider weniger zu gebrauchen.

Folglich kann ich jedem empfehlen

column10: sich auf einen Platz in drei der insgesamt vier verschiedenen Studentenwohnheime zu bewerben. Den Erfahrungen meiner Vorgänger entsprechend habe ich mich für das Wohnheim Lappis als erste Priorität entschieden und glücklicherweise auch einen entsprechenden Platz angeboten bekommen. column11: die keinen Platz in Lappis bekommen haben
column12: waren aber auch mit ihren Unterkünften sehr zufrieden.;"Die Stockholm University zählt mit über 70.000 Studenten zu den größten Universitäten Skandinaviens und genießt im Allgemeinen einen guten Ruf. Im Gegensatz zu Mannheim nimmt die Business School innerhalb der Universität allerdings keine Sonderstellung ein. Das Semester an der Stockholm University ist in vier jeweils sechswöchige Abschnitte gegliedert. In jedem der vier Abschnitte wird in der Regel ein Kurs à 7.5 ECTS belegt
column13: allerdings gibt es auch Kurse
column14: die sich über zwei Perioden erstrecken. Bei der Notenumrechnung ist zu beachten
column15: dass die meisten der 7.5-ECTS-Kurse nur als 6-ECTS-Kurse anerkannt werden (Ausnahme: Anrechnung als International Course). Demgemäß entspricht ein Vollzeitstudium an der SU nicht notwendigerweise einem 30-ECTS-Semester in Mannheim. Offiziell geht das Herbst-/Wintersemester bis Mitte Januar. Viele der Kurse der letzten Periode schließen jedoch bereits vor Weihnachten ab
column16: sodass es bei entsprechender Planung auf jeden Fall möglich sein sollte

column1: Im Vergleich zu Mannheim habe ich den Arbeitsaufwand und das akademische Niveau an der Stockholm University als etwas geringer wahrgenommen. Folglich lässt sich das Austauschsemester gut mit außeruniversitären Aktivitäten vereinbaren

column1: Eine interessante Möglichkeit für SU-Studenten besteht darin
column2: Kurse an der Stockholm School of Entrepreneurship (SSES) zu belegen. Die SSES ist ein Gemeinschaftsprojekt verschiedener Stockholmer Universitäten (u.a. des renommierten KTHs und der Stockhom School of Economics) und bietet institutsübergreifende Kurse im Bereich Entrepreneurship an. Zwar scheint das Kursniveau auch an der SSES je nach Lehrperson zu schwanken

column1: Der für viele womöglich größte Nachteil an einem längeren Schwedenaufenthalt besteht im kalten Klima. Während die Sommermonate zwar mild aber in der Regel sonnig sind

column4: dass man sich nach einiger Zeit an die besonderen Bedingungen gewöhnt und die Dunkelheit als kein wirkliches Problem empfunden.

column1: Stockholm ist in meinen Augen eine der sehenswertesten Städte Europas. In der Stadt gibt es zahlreiche Einkaufsmöglichkeiten
column2: Museen
column3: und Cafés. Besonders empfehlen kann ich einen Besuch im bekannten Vasa Museum

Ebenfalls zu empfehlen ist ein Besuch der zahlreichen Sportstädten der Stadt (besonders für Fußball und Eishockey scheinen sich die Schweden zu begeistern). Bei schönem Wetter lohnt außerdem eine Fahrt mit der Fähre zu den zahlreichen der Stadt vorgelagerten Inseln („Schären“). Auch was das Nachtleben angeht hat Stockholm einiges zu bieten. Passend zur schwedischen Kultur wird dabei in vielen Clubs und  Bars auf hochwertige Kleidung und gesittetes Verhalten wert gelegt. Exzessives Betrinken findet

column3: und Oslo ist es in jedem Fall empfehlenswert einen der zahlreichen schwedischen Nationalparks zu besuchen.  Auch die schwedischen Städte Göteborg
column4: Upsala und Örebrö sind sehr sehenswert. Ich selbst bin bereits drei  Wochen vor dem Semesterstart nach Schweden gereist und habe eine längere Camping-Tour ans Nordkapp und durch Norwegen gemacht. Im Winter werden außerdem Lappland Touren einschließlich Schlittenhundfahrten
column5: Eishotelübernachtungen und Nordlichtwanderungen angeboten.

column1: Ein besonderes Highlight während dem Semester war eine Kreuzfahrt nach St. Petersburg (die einzige Möglichkeit für EU-Bürger visafrei nach Russland einzureisen). Dazu gibt es von Stockholm aus die Möglichkeit relativ günstige Kreuzfahrten
column2: zum Beispiel ins Baltikum oder nach Finnland zu unternehmen.

Und im Vergleich zu Übersee-Aufenthalten gestaltet sich immerhin die die Anreise als günstiger. Ich habe etwa einen Monat vor Reiseantritt meinen Flug von Frankfurt nach Stockholm (Arlanda) gebucht und  für Hin- und Rückreise etwas weniger als 200 Euro gezahlt. Bei frühzeitigerer Buchung kann es durchaus möglich sein noch günstigere Tickets zu bekommen.

column1: Als EU Bürger kann man problemlos mit einem deutschen Personalausweis in Schweden einreisen. Ein Visum muss nicht beantragt werden. Lediglich für den erwähnten Kurztrip nach St. Petersburg ist ein Reisepass notwendige Voraussetzung.

column1: Here are the documents I used for the application: 1. signed application form (acquired when you fill your information online); 2. list of priorities; 3. transcripts;4. GMAT; 5. IELTS; 6. CV; 7. motivation letter.
To study in Switzerland
column2: Non-EU students need to apply the visa in the general consulate of Switzerland in Germany. I went to the one in Frankfurt
column3: applied in May and got it in August. I suggest that you apply the visa as soon as you are sure to go to Switzerland because the process takes 8-12 weeks. The visa for student is free and you don’t need to make any appointment. Be sure you have all the documents they require before you go there.

column1: They provide a Buddy program for the exchange students. I suggest you should join it. It is a really good way to know local Swiss students and they can help you a lot before and after your arrival. The host university will send you an email about this program.";"As for accommodation
column2: I suggest you apply on the website of FMEL. You need to pay attention to the time for register since the portal is not always available for registration all the time. The rents for the apartment are listed online
column3: which increases a little bit each year. The room is equipped with all the furniture you need. You share the kitchen with other people.

column1: However
column2: I found the private apartment
column3: shared with other two girls
column4: which took me 650 CHF per month. I live in community Chavannes-près-Renens
column5: where the rent is lower than that of the city center. Usually
column6: it took me 20 minutes by tram to the university. There are 3 tram station for the Unil
column7: so make sure you get off at the right one. Or else it will be easily got lost in such a large university.

column1: Besides the dorm and private housing
column2: you could also join some local Facebook groups to search for your room. There are several good offers that are near to the university and with a reasonable price. In conclusion
column3: the early the better.";"The courses are listed online and all the details are included. But the updated information for courses is available just before the semester start. So be patient if you could not get the newest information for you learning agreement.

column1: You could take the language course from EFLE (Ecole de français langue étrangère). They provide us with French course for different levels. The course information could be obtained on the welcome day. So be sure you are there on this important day. However
column2: the credits from language course could not be acknowledged for MMM students by Uni Mannheim.

column1: The lectures are longer in average than those in Mannheim
column2: which means that you need to attend a 4-hour lecture for a 6-credit course. But this could be helpful in the other hand
column3: the group discussion are available during this longer lecture. Most of the master courses are taught in English
column4: but there are still courses taught in French available.

column1: The canteen could be found in almost every building. Each meal costs between 7 to 13 CHF. But you could receive a discount with your student card. The best one I believe is the one in building l’Unithèque
column2: where you can have lots of different choices and the prices are lower than other canteen like that in building Géopolis.";"Lausanne is a very beautiful city
column3: locating by the lac Léman and opposing the Alps. One the best place to enjoy such wonderful scenery is the building l’Unithèque. Sitting by the table and drinking a cup of coffee right outside this building
column4: I enjoy the sunshine and scenery in the afternoon
column5: which could be one of my favorite things during my exchange semester. Running along lac Léman could also be a perfect opportunity to get know it.

column1: If you want to travel in Switzerland
column2: I recommend you the half-tariff card from SBB
column3: which allows you a half price for train tickets and some discount for bus or tram tickets. The transport expenses are quite high in Switzerland
column4: so if you plan to travel around
column5: buying the card early could save you a lot of money.

column1: The ESN Unil (an organization which organize events for international students) organized lots of events (including party
column2: concerts
column3: skiing
column4: climbing). You can join them on the welcome day and get a discount for each event with the membership card.";In general
column5: the living cost in Lausanne could be 2 times that in Mannheim. First
column6: whenever you take the flight

column8: you obtain the visa with no expense because it’s for student. Third
column9: the housing could be a large part of you living cost
column10: around 650-1200 CHF
column11: which depends on the place and type of your apartment. Fourth
column12: I go to the supermarket twice a week and it costs me around 30 CHF each time. There are several different supermarkets in Switzerland and the commons are Coop
column13: Migros
column14: Denner and Lidl. Fifth
column15: for the transport in Lausanne

column19: the meal in a restaurant costs around 30 CHF per person. Finally
column20: the month expenses in Lausanne could be at least 1200 CHF.;The Swiss government offers a scholarship with 2100 CHF for my whole exchange semester. This could not cover all of the living cost in Switzerland but it helps a lot as a compensation for such high living expense.;"My exchange semester lasted from September to January. And I chose four courses (Corporate Finance
column21: Investment
column22: Marketing Science
column23: Strategic Marketing)
column24: 6 ECTS each. These courses are all taught in English. I have to say that studying in Unil is not an easy thing since the group work takes up most of your spare time.

column1: Corporate Finance - 6ECTS
Final grade = 20%*project + 20*individual assignment (four assignments) + 60*final exam (3 hours)
15:15 - 19:00 every Tuesday
This course provides you with basic corporate finance knowledge (including time value of money
column2: capital budgeting
column3: valuation
column4: bankruptcy
column5: agency costs). I don’t recommend students who study in finance take this course since this is too easy for them. But if you’re a student studying in marketing or accounting and interested in finance
column6: I strongly recommend you take this course to get a thorough view of finance.

column1: Investment - 6ECTS
Final grade = 100%* final exam (3 hours)
13:15 – 17:00 every Thursday
This course is also a basic course in finance
column2: which I would recommend for those who are not studying finance. It covers the stocks and bonds
column3: CAPM
column4: market efficiency
column5: anomalies
column6: valuation
column7: trading and commodities. The professor was very nice and he explained everything whenever you were confused. Usually the course ended at 16:00. There were four assignments (not required but for exercises) and four exercise class (not mandatory) during the semester.

column1: Marketing Science - 6ECTS
Final grade = 35*case study(group work) + 15*simulation work (two group work) + 50%* final exam (2 hours)

This course introduces many tools and methods to quantify the decisions. It covers the methods to create and predict customer values and evaluate customer values. The first simulation was to predict the demand and supply during a financial crisis in both developing and developed countries. The second simulation was a regression analysis to bid the price with other groups. The two cases were about the STP method. The professor was really nice and kind to us and he was always there if you had any questions. If you are interested in quantitative marketing
column2: I strongly recommend you this course. You will learn a lot and find it really useful.

column1: Strategic Marketing - 6ECTS
Final grade = 50*case study(group work) + 50%* final exam (2 hours)
08:00 – 12:00 every Friday
This course consists two parts: B2B and B2C
column2: which were taught by two professors. In B2C part
column3: STP method
column4: branding management and relationship management were included. In B2C part
column5: products strategies
column6: segmentation
column7: buying decisions and sales strategies were included. There were two cases
column8: one from B2C and one from B2B. The course was about qualitative marketing. Thus
column9: I recommend this course to those who are interested in strategy management since concepts and cases are the most important part for this course.";I really enjoyed the semester I spent in Lausanne and I appreciated all the people I met there. Thank you for their help that allows me to have such a wonderful and unforgettable experience. The best memory is about a friend I met there who was an exchange student from Tokyo. We studied together
column10: traveled together and had a lot of fun. column3: welches für ein Studium in Südafrika benötigt wird. Der organisatorische Aufwand ist recht hoch und man sollte genug Zeit einplanen und am besten möglichst früh damit beginnen die benötigten Unterlagen zu sammeln - Finanz Nachweise
column4: Gutachten von Ärzten uvm. (eine Übersicht gibt es auf der Seite des Konsulats).

column1: Die Ankunft in Kapstadt wurde von der USB sehr gut organisiert. Man konnte im voraus angeben wann man am Flughafen ankommt und wohin man möchte und wurde dann von einem Fahrer abgeholt und an sein Wunschziel gefahren. Wir Austauschstudenten hatten uns schon ein paar Wochen vorher in einer facebook Gruppe organisiert und für die ersten Nächte in einem Hostel verabredet - das “91 Loop” kann ich sehr empfehlen. Von hier aus begann dann die Wohnungssuche.";Was die Unterkunft angeht stellt sich zu Beginn die Frage ob Kapstadt oder Stellenbosch. Ich
column2: wie alle anderen Austauschstudenten auch
column3: habe mich für Kapstadt entschieden. Kapstadt ist ein tolle Stadt mit schier endlosen kulturellen
column4: kulinarischen
column5: und sportlichen Angeboten und insgesamt einfach einer grandiosen Lebensqualität. Stellenbosch ist aber sicher auch nett und bietet mehr studentisches Leben auf dem Campus. Was die Nähe zur Uni angeht liegen beide Orte ähnlich. Allerdings hat Kapstadt hier den Vorteil
column6: dass man morgens und abends entgegen des Pendlerverkehrs fährt und somit nicht im Stau steht. Der Verkehr zu den Stoßzeiten in Kapstadt ist extrem und sollte nicht unterschätzt werden - hier werden aus 15min Fahrzeit gerne mal eine Stunde. Viertel in Kapstadt die ich empfehlen würde sind Gardens (und umliegende Viertel)
column7: Sea Point
column8: Green Point und Observatory. Ich selbst habe in Observatory in einer WG mit zwei südafrikanischen Studentinnen gewohnt. Observatory ist deutlich günstiger als die zentralen Viertel
column9: hier leben viele Studenten der UCT
column10: und auch die Lage ist eigentlich recht praktisch - genau mittig zwischen USB
column11: City Center
column12: und Surf Stränden. Auch mit local Studenten zu leben war eine tolle Erfahrunge weil ich so denke ich mehr von der Kultur mitbekommen habe und über meine Mitbewohner und die offene Art der Südafrikaner sehr schnell viele Leute kennen lernen durfte. Diese WG habe ich über die facebook Gruppen “HUIS HUIS” und “HUIS HUIS Southern Suburbs” gefunden. Um ein gemietetes Auto kommt man unabhängig vom Wohnort eigentlich nicht herum. Manche der Studenten haben sich ein Auto geteilt. Da ich nicht mit anderen Austauschstudenten gelebt habe
column13: habe ich mir ein eigenes gemietet. Ich habe über Frank Fuchs ein super Angebot bekommen. Er betreibt auch einen “German Grocer”
column14: wo man auch seine Kontaktdaten findet: https://www.germangrocercapetown.co.za/;"Das Kursangebot war deutlich kleiner als zB in Mannheim. Dennoch ist eigentlich aus fast allen Bereichen etwas dabei. Gegen Ende des Semesters findet dann noch die Elective Week statt. Hier werden geblockt innerhalb einer Woche nochmal Wahlkurse angeboten. Hier ist die Auswahl deutlich größer. Insgesamt hielt sich der Aufwand für die von mir gewählten Kurse in Grenzen. Ich hatte ein bis zwei mal die Woche Vorlesungen und dazwischen mussten Kapitel aus den Büchern gelesen und Online Quizzes zu diesen Kapiteln bearbeitet werden. Zwischen dem Ende und dem Start meiner Kurse kam es auch mal vor
column15: dass ich zwei bis drei Wochen keine Vorlesungen hatte. In dieser Zeit mussten dann Paper und Gruppenarbeiten geschrieben werden. Wir Austauschstudenten haben immer versucht das in einem Push zu erledigen um die restliche Zeit reisen zu können. Das hat sehr gut funktioniert.

Im Vergleich zu den anderen Kursen eher hart benotet.";"Für mich war die beste Erfahrung der Alltag in Kapstadt. Ich bin begeisterter Berg- und Brett-Sportler und daher war das Leben zwischen Bergen und Meer einfach paradiesisch. Das in Kombination mit der offenen und gelassenen Art der Südafrikaner und der tollen Gemeinschaft unter den Austauschstudenten hat meine sechs Monate in Kapstadt zu einer unvergesslichen Zeit gemacht.

column1: Die schlechteste Erfahrung
column2: war leider teilweise die Organisation und Kommunikation mit der Uni (USB). Da herrschte leider oft Chaos und die Kommunikation mit der Uni gestaltete sich oft sehr zäh
column3: wenn es darum ging Probleme zu lösen. Zuletzt wurden bei mir beispielsweise mehrere Noten falsch berechnet und es hat mich viel Zeit gekostet diese Fehler korrigieren zu lassen. Im Endeffekt hat dann aber doch alles geklappt. Wenn man also hier eine gesunde Portion Gelassenheit mitbringt
column4: kann man damit auch gut leben.

column1: Insgesamt ist diese “schlechteste Erfahrung” also nur ein kleiner Schatten auf einem ansonsten absolut fantastischem Auslandssemester!";https://www.service4mobility.com/mannheim/DispQuestionServlet?identifier=MANNHEI01&kz_call=A&sprache=de&org_id=72&q_set_nr=ERFAHRUNGSBERICHT&pk_table_name=bewerbung&pk_name=bew_id&inst_id_logo=413686&use_jsp=1&pk_id=209597&bew_id=209597;2024-04-21 23:09:01.580254
188;Südafrika;ZASTELLEN01 - University of Stellenbosch Business School (USB);2017/2018;Fakultät für Betriebswirtschaftslehre - BWL;Management (MMM)
column2: Master - BWL_M_BWL;265007;"In order to apply for the USB you need 18 months of work experience (internships count).  After I was nominated by Uni Mannheim I had to apply to the USB
column3: but this was fairly easy as it was an online system where you just input your data and upload your documents such as CV
column4: recommendation letters
column5: language certificate
column6: etc. We also had to send them the subject registration form
column7: which was completely useless as the courses and when they were to take place changed many times over. Due to this I was only able to organize my learning agreements when I was already in South Africa but this was no problem as the chairs in Mannheim all responded quickly. Once I was officially accepted by the USB I began the visa process.

column1: Begin the Visa process as soon as possible! There are 3 pages full of documents that you need in order to apply for a Visa and getting the individual documents usually takes some time as well. For example you need health certificates from doctors
column2: your police record
column3: certified bank statements
column4: etc. Then you either have to go to the consulate in Berlin or Munich in person to drop off your documents. When they finally mailed me my passport it was 3 weeks before I was supposed to leave for South Africa and they had made a mistake on my visa and had only given me one for 4 months instead of 6. I therefore had to go to Munich again. Others from my exchange program also had mistakes in their visas. Therefore start with the visa application process as soon as you get accepted.

column1: Communication from the USB was not very good. We received almost no information from them until a few weeks before the program was about to start. In general the organization of the university cannot be compared to Mannheim. For example
column2: the university forgot to give us access to half of the classes on the online portal and gave us the wrong lecture times for certain classes. However the people from the university are all really nice and will try and help you wherever they can. The university organizes a really cool introduction week for exchange students the week before classes start filled with activities such as wine tours
column3: township visits
column4: etc. So be sure to arrive at least a week before classes start. The university sent us the contact info of the other exchange students so we set up a Facebook group where we communicated and then decided to meet up at the same hostel to go apartment hunting together.";The university offers student dorms but these are located in Stellenbosch so it made little sense to stay there as the business school is in Bellville and everyone from my semester stayed in Cape Town anyways. I would recommend to stay in Cape Town as the city offers a lot more than Stellenbosch. Just be aware that if you decide to stay in Cape Town you are foregoing the campus life that Stellenbosch offers. Do not live in Bellville (where the university is)
column5: nothing happens there. It is located between Stellenbosch and Cape Town.  I was very happy with my decision to live in Cape Town because the city offers so many different opportunities for activities
column6: nightlife
column7: etc. I chose to live in Sea Point with two other exchange students. The best areas to live are Sea Point
column8: Gardens and Green Point. You will need a car to get to university and the commute takes between 20 - 45 min depending on the traffic and time of day. Depending on the season you go the prices for accommodation vary widely. In the offseason (HWS) the prices are very reasonable and for a little more than you pay in Mannheim you can get luxurious apartments with a sea view. We paid 20
column9: 000 ZAR a month for our 3 bedroom 4 bathroom apartment with balcony
column10: pool
column11: etc. However in the high season the prices are 3-4 times higher. We waited until we got to Cape Town to apartment hunt together. We ended up finding our apartment through Airbnb
column12: but also used local realtors and the internet. The services from the realtors are free and they are very helpful. In total cost of living is more expensive
column13: since you definitely need a car to get around. We rented ours from rentacheapie and were happy with them. Since I lived with 2 other exchange students we just split the cost of renting the car which was convenient. I never took public transportation as we were told it is unsafe. However I did use Uber a lot and found it to be very convenient
column14: safe and cheap especially for getting around at night.;"Classes at USB are in English. The USB itself does not offer any language classes but some language classes are offered at the main campus in Stellenbosch. The campus in Bellville is very small and the MBA students are all quite a bit older
column15: as such there is no campus life like there is in Stellenbosch or Mannheim. The campus however does have a small canteen/ café and a small library. We were able to choose classes from the MBA and the Post Graduate Diploma Program. Overall the choice in main classes is very limited
column16: but in the HWS you have the option to choose from a wide variety of elective classes that are offered in the last weeks in a block type schedule. The university has a semester schedule but since the MBA students have their theses towards the end of the year we only had MBA classes for around 2 months and then had Post Graduate Diploma classes the next 2 months followed by the electives. The structure of the courses is a lot different than in Mannheim. Most everything is done online or on the computer. In addition to a final exam there are also quizzes and assignments for each course throughout the semester. The levels of the courses also vary. I found the Post Graduate Diploma classes to be quite easy
column17: whereas the corporate finance class from the MBA program was quite rigorous. The class sizes are around 30 people
column18: which encourages a lot of interaction and class discussion. I was able to receive equivalent credit in Mannheim for 2 classes and received international study credits for my other two classes. The grading in South Africa is rather interesting as 80% is a 1.0 in Mannheim. However getting above 80% on assignments or exams is uncommon
column19: but with the quizzes you can usually push your grades up.

column1: There was a 10
column2: 000 ZAR administrative fee that we had to pay at the beginning of the semester so be aware of that when budgeting your trip.";"Cape Town is an awesome city to live in
column3: there are endless amounts of things to do (see the list at the end of the paragraph). However one should always be aware that Cape Town is still South Africa and there is unfortunately a lot of crime. My tips would be to always be aware of your surroundings
column4: don't walk around alone at night
column5: never leave anything in the car and never let anyone approach you while you are at the ATM. I think just by using common sense everything will be fine.

column1: Cape Town is also currently experiencing a water crisis
column2: which is causing huge problems for the city so do try and save water. In South Africa it is common courtesy to tip people for everything including “watching” your car when you park it.

column1: Some people experience culture shock when they first come here due to the huge divide between rich and poor. Cape Town is a very beautiful and modern city
column2: yet a large portion of Greater Cape Town residents live a few kilometers away in former township areas.

column1: The weather is perfect
column2: its warm and the sun shines almost everyday. If you go in HWS it is their winter in July/ August so be sure to bring a light jacket as it does get chilly sometimes.

column1: In and around Cape Town there are so many cool things to do here is a selection:
-	Beaches: Clifton
column2: Camp's Bay
column3: Bloubergstrand

column1: -	Hiking: Lion's Head
column2: Devil's Peak
column3: Silvermine Trail
column4: Table Mountain

column1: -	Surfing: Muizenberg
-	Lion's Head paragliding
-	Robben Island
-	Kirstenbosch Botanical Gardens
-	Long Street has lots of bars and clubs
-	Stellenbosch and Franschoek for vineyards and wine tastings
column2: Franschoek has a hop on hop off wine tram

column1: Travel tips outside of Cape Town
-	Garden Route to Port Elizabeth
-	Kruger National Park safari
-	Hermanus for whale watching
-	Gansbaai for shark cage diving
-	If you have time go to Botswana and Namibia the wildlife and nature there is incredible";"What amount should an outgoing student budget for regarding:
- Flight / Journey: 700-900 Euros
- Housing: 400 - 500 Euros/ month

- Cost of living per month (in general and compared to life in Mannheim): cost of living is more expensive due to renting a car and doing more activities I would budget around 1000 Euros";I don't know about any specific funding opportunities or scholarships
column2: but I would recommend to get a credit/ debit card which lets you withdraw money from ATMS without any fees.;"Corporate Finance-->	FIN 550 International Course	8 ECTS	This course was demanding but very interesting and well taught. I enjoyed it and learned a lot. We had quizzes
column3: group assignment and 2 exams.

column1: Innovation Management-->	MAN 690 Innovation Management	6 ECTS	Nice introduction to innovation management. We had an exam
column2: quizzes and an assignment.

column1: Principles of Operations-->	OPM 550 International Course	5 ECTS	Gives an overview of operations. We had an exam
column2: quizzes and an assignment.

column1: Entrepreneurship -->	MAN 630 Introduction to Entrepreneurship	6 ECTS	This was an elective. We had one group assignment and one individual assignment.";I can only recommend Cape Town and the USB. I had an incredible time in Cape Town between the weather
column2: the nature
column3: all the activities
column4: and bars and restaurants you will never run out of things to do. It is one of the coolest cities to live in. There is also so much to explore in South Africa and the surrounding countries so my advice would be to take advantage of everything the region has to offer.;https://www.service4mobility.com/mannheim/DispQuestionServlet?identifier=MANNHEI01&kz_call=A&sprache=de&org_id=72&q_set_nr=ERFAHRUNGSBERICHT&pk_table_name=bewerbung&pk_name=bew_id&inst_id_logo=413686&use_jsp=1&pk_id=209631&bew_id=209631;2024-04-21 23:09:02.806248

column1: 189;Südkorea;KRSEOUL01 - KAIST College of Business;2017/2018;Fakultät für Betriebswirtschaftslehre - BWL;Management (MMM)
column2: Master - BWL_M_BWL;265021;"Preparation

column1: Every step of the whole process from the application to the experience report can be tracked in the Mobility Online portal and is very well organized by the International Office. The International Office informs students shortly before Christmas about their exchange spot.
After a successful application to the International Office
column2: you need to submit documents to KAIST for the official application until the end of March. A list of required documents is provided by Ji Eun Lee
column3: the exchange coordinator at KAIST. Ji Eun is your contact person for every matter. She and her team are very kind and take care of exchange students very thoughtfully. Prior to the exchange semester
column4: Ji Eun frequently sends out emails with useful information regarding the certificate of admission
column5: dormitory information and other required documents.

column1: The certificate of admission is needed for the visa application (D-2-6 Student Exchange Program Visa) and unfortunately arrives quite late at the end of May. As the application process takes ca. 3 weeks according to the Korean embassy in Frankfurt and I already went to Asia in June
column2: I decided to apply for the visa directly at the embassy in Singapore. That was no problem at all and only took couple of days. In addition
column3: KAIST also requires a physical checkup and proof of medical insurance that I had to send to Ji Eun until the beginning of August. Unfortunately
column4: the physical checkup also includes a tuberculosis screening test that is subject to a charge and takes about a week for the results.

column1: Arrival

Most international flights arrive at Incheon airport from where it takes quite a while to get to the campus. The school recommends taking the airport limousine bus 6101 to Korea University station and from there a taxi to the dorm. The bus costs KRW 15
column2: 000 and the taxi KRW 4
column3: 000 for a 5-minutes ride. Detailed information about that is provided by KAIST in the student survival guide. Instead of the bus
column4: a cheaper alternative is to take the subway from the airport to Hoegi Station via Seoul station which costs ca. KRW 5
column5: 000 and from there a taxi for KRW 4
column6: 000. However
column7: this option requires you to transfer at Seoul Station so if you have a lot of luggage
column8: the bus is more convenient.";"While KAIST’s main campus is actually in Daejon (150km from Seoul)
column9: the College of Business is located in Seoul. The campus is very small
column10: consisting only of a few buildings
column11: sports fields and the dorms.

column1: Every exchange student at KAIST has the possibility to rent a double room for a very low price (640
column2: 000 KRW for the whole semester
column3: ca. EUR 500). The dorm where exchange students stay is called Pajongsa and has several floors whereby floors are divided in men’s and women’s.

column1: Usually a room is shared with a roommate from the same country. If you want
column2: however
column3: you can ask to stay with a Korean student. Like most exchange students
column4: I chose to stay with another exchange student and I had a very good experience with my roommate. It’s likely that you’re in the same social circle and hang out anyway. Most Korean students only stay in the dorm during weekdays and go home on weekends. The room is equipped with a bed
column5: a desk and a wardrobe. The mattresses are a little old so be prepared to feel some springs. No bedding is provided so you either need to bring some from home or buy new bedding in Seoul. Bedding is available at Lotte Department Store (Cheongnyangni) or for little bit less money at E-Mart (Wangsimni). If you act quickly
column6: you can also try to secure old bedding that has been left behind by former exchange students. Ji Eun
column7: the exchange coordinator
column8: will provide a list in the Facebook group.

column1: Bathrooms and toilets are shared in each wing and are quite clean most of the time as they are cleaned every day during weekdays. On every wing
column2: there is a washing machines that can be used for free. There are additional washing machines and dryers on the top floor. There is also a small kitchen with fridges on the top floor so that you can cook if you want. As it’s quite inexpensive to eat out
column3: most of us never used the kitchen.

column1: Eating out
column2: however
column3: requires a little effort since the campus is located on a hill. It takes at least a 10 minutes’ walk downhill just to get some food (and the same way uphill again). Fortunately
column4: food options in the Hoegi area are aplenty. To get to one of the two closest subway stations (Hoegi or Korea University)
column5: you need to walk 15-20 minutes from the campus or take the bus in front of the campus.

column1: Despite the inconvenient location and some minor flaws
column2: I would definitely recommend staying in the dorm. First of all
column3: the price cannot be beaten in an expensive city like Seoul. Second
column4: the way to class is short
column5: as well as to other facilities such as the gym or the table tennis room. And finally
column6: the large majority of the exchange students stays in the dorm so there’s always someone to hang out and do something.";"KAIST is one of the most prestigious universities in South Korea. It is primarily known as science and engineering institution
column7: but the College of Business is also one of the leading business schools in Asia. While the main campus is in Daejon (150 km south of Seoul)
column8: the business faculty is located in Seoul. Therefore
column9: the campus is small and campus life is rather quiet.Like in many other countries
column10: at KAIST the grade is composed of many different parts. You are graded on attendance
column11: assignments
column12: group projects
column13: presentations and
column14: of course
column15: exams. As an exchange student you can choose - as far as I know - any course at the College of Business in Seoul. It is
column16: for instance
column17: also possible to take some courses from programs like Green Policy or Management Economics. However
column18: if you don’t know Korean
column19: you’re restricted to English courses so that in fact most of the students took courses from the Techno MBA (business administration courses) and Finance MBA. Almost all Techno MBA courses are full semester courses and grant 3 credits (equivalent to 6 ECTS). Many Finance MBA courses
column20: on the other hand
column21: are only half semester courses and consequently are only worth 1.5 credits (3 ECTS). The advantage of full semester courses is that many courses don’t have midterms so that you can use the midterm week to travel.Course registration at KAIST is done online during the add-and-drop phase and was hassle-free for me.The course catalog is large enough and at least in the fall semester there are some courses that can be recognized as equivalent course in Mannheim. The final course list
column22: however
column23: is only published shortly before the semester. And as I was already abroad before my exchange semester
column24: I applied for the learning agreements by email which was no problem. All the courses that I wanted to take had enough spots and I also didn’t hear of any problems from other students. If a course has any kind of restrictions
column25: it’s usually worth talking to the professor. For example
column26: I wanted to take Financial Databases which was restricted to Finance MBA students because it’s a mandatory course for them and the school wanted to make sure that there enough spots. But after asking the professor it was no problem to take the course. In general
column27: the professors at KAIST are very friendly and try to help as best as they can.Class size is relatively small with no more than 40 students per class. The student body is quite diverse with Korean students
column28: exchange students (mostly from Europe)
column29: KOICA students (government officials from emerging economies; mostly from Africa)
column30: and other international students. In the MBA courses
column31: the majority of the students have significant work experience and are therefore older than the typical master’s student from Europe. Although the professors welcome active contribution
column32: classes are rather teacher-centered with the professor lecturing the students.The school hosts great facilities with modern classrooms and plenty of places to study. For group work
column33: there are seminar rooms on the 2nd floor in the SUPEX building (by the way
column34: like in most Asian countries
column35: the ground-floor is denoted as 1st floor) and lots of other rooms splattered on each floor. For individual studying
column36: there are the student labs
column37: the library or the study rooms on the 3rd floor in Building 9. A student lab is a room with cubicles for up to 10 students. Every student is assigned a fixed desk in one of the student labs for the entire time at KAIST. This is very convenient as you can leave your belongings there. Each lab is equipped with a printer which can be used for free. In addition
column38: the lab provides a good opportunity to meet Korean students; many labs organize lab dinners to get to know each other. The only downside was that the lab was just heated in the daytime and it could get really cold during the winter. A few labs have mobile heaters that someone brought along. If not
column39: the library as well as the study rooms in building 9 are equipped with heaters. Alternatively
column40: at night you can also use one of the classrooms which are always open. We made use of that several times to watch movies and football matches on a big screen.Apart from teaching facilities
column41: the school also has a wide range of recreation facilities that can be used for free. There is a gym which is rather small but has everything that is needed for a good workout (treadmills
column42: machines
column43: free weights). In the student union building there is a table tennis room on the 1st floor. Right next to the dorm there are also tennis courts
column44: a basketball court and a badminton court.";"Seoul is an absolutely marvelous city to spend a semester. It’s sprawling
column45: vibrant and exciting
column46: home to over 10 million people who are fond of technology
column47: fashion and K-Pop.

column1: Due to the size of Seoul
column2: each district is like an own city with lots of shops
column3: supermarkets
column4: restaurants
column5: coffee shops and bars. From Monday to Thursday
column6: we usually spent a lot of time in the area around campus
column7: called Hoegi. As mentioned before
column8: we often opted to have lunch and dinner in Hoegi. There are lots of restaurants and it’s a good representation of typical eateries in Seoul
column9: comprising of well-known chains
column10: traditional family-run restaurants
column11: “hofs” (chicken and beer) and of course barbeque places. Overall
column12: food is fantastic
column13: so just be open to explore new
column14: unknown things. Apart from restaurants
column15: there is a  large amount of coffee shops - often with several stories - to hang out or study.

column1: On the weekends
column2: we used our spare time to do sightseeing and to enjoy Seoul’s fabolous nightlife (more details below). The city’s must-sees are the royal palaces (Gyeongbokgung
column3: Changdeokgung)
column4: the traditional village (Bukchon Hanok Village)
column5: the observation tower (Namsan Tower) and the nearby mountain (Bukhansan). For shopping
column6: there is the touristy district Myeongdong or Dongdaemun (especially clothes)
column7: which is closer to the campus. For food
column8: apart from the restaurants all over the city
column9: the markets are worth a visit. Kwangjang Market offers a wide variety of food
column10: ranging from Korean pancakes to raw beef (Yukhoe). For seafood
column11: go to the newly renovated Noryangjin Fish Market. It's huge! After buying fresh fish on the first floor you can bring your catch up to the second floor and have it cooked or grilled by one of the many restaurants there. The price negotiation was a bit challenging
column12: but it’s a cool experience. In the summer
column13: the Hangang Park at the riverside is a lovely place to wind down and have a picnic. Locals usually have chicken and beer delivered to their place.

column1: During the night
column2: there is an unexplainable energy in the city. In my opinion
column3: the nightlife in Seoul is second to none and deserves special mention. Koreans really live in line with the “Work hard play hard”-principle which is probably the reason why restaurants and bars are always buzzing no matter what day of the week it is. It’s not unusual to find people having Soju along with side dishes on a Monday night. Different from a night out in Germany
column4: going out in Korae in general involves more venues and the party never ends before dawn. Popular districts to go out in Seoul are Itaewon
column5: Hongdae and Gangnam
column6: each with its own character. We often went to Itaewon or Hongdae which is about 30 minutes and 40 minutes
column7: respectively
column8: away by taxi or subway from KAIST. Typically
column9: the night starts with a “main dinner” and is directly followed by a “second dinner”. The focus shifts more to drinking at the second dinner
column10: but food is still involved. After this
column11: it’s usually time for a bar or two before entering a club. For those still not tired
column12: there are after-clubs as well. And the truly great thing about the nightlife is that despite all the drinking
column13: it’s always peaceful and safe.

column1: On some weekends
column2: we also made trips outside of Seoul. For example
column3: many exchange students and I went to the Seoraksan National Park
column4: which is a very beautiful park to hike. I also made trips to Jeju Island
column5: the DMZ and Nami Island. Due to a very lucky constellation in 2017
column6: we had more than a week of public holidays during the Korean Thanksgiving (Chuseok) which allowed us to make an extended trip to Japan as well.

column1: If you go in the fall semester
column2: try to do all outdoor-related activities as soon as possible because it gets extremely cold in the winter. The summers in Korea are hot and humid and then there is only a short fall which quickly transitions into winter. When I was there
column3: we already had the first snow in November and temperatures were as low as -5° to -15° from then on.";"Before studying in Korea
column4: you need to apply for a student visa which is fortunately for free. Prices of flight tickets
column5: of course
column6: vary and depend on the departure day and the time of booking. Direct round-trips from Germany to Korea usally cost 700-1000 EUR as far as I know. But I wouldn't recommend to book the return flight yet if you plan to travel afterwards. If you're lucky you can find cheap open jaw flights as I did. After the semester
column7: I flew from Seoul to Taipei
column8: from Taipei to Shanghai and from Shanghai to Frankfurt for less than 500 EUR.

column1: Seoul is frequently mentioned as one of the most expensive cities in the world. This is primarily due to expensive housing
column2: but as a KAIST student you'll have a guaranteed spot in the cheap dorm which saves a lot of money. Apart from that
column3: Seoul is very affordable with simple everyday meals ranging from 2-7 EUR. As I didn't cook myself
column4: I spent approximately 15-20 EUR for food and drinks
column5: including 2-4 EUR for a coffee (coffee is indeed expensive). Drinking alcohol
column6: on the other hand
column7: is cheap. The typical Koraen spirit
column8: Soju
column9: costs only 1-1.5 EUR per bottle in convenience stores
column10: beers cost 2-3 EUR. Clubs are a bit pricey as they usually ask for a cover charge of 7-15 EUR.

column1: Public transport is very cheap and costs less than 1 EUR per trip. Get a T-Money card at a convenience store and top it up to pay easily. Taxis are generelly cheap
column2: but if there is a lot of demand (e.g. during the night)
column3: some taxi drivers try to rip you off and ask for a higher price. Usually
column4: it pays off to negotiate or to look for a nicer driver. Flights to Jeju Island are also inexpensive as round trips cost between 50-100 EUR.";-;"FMB552EB Financial Databases / 3 ECTS / Recognized as IS 550 International Course / Grading: Participation and attendance
column5: 2 group assignments
column6: Bloomberg Market Concepts certificate
column7: final group project and presentation
column8: final exam / As you can already infer from the grading policy
column9: this half semester course has a heavy workload. If you’re interested in acquiring some basic skills in R and SQL and applying those to financial data
column10: it’s definitely worth it. The professor
column11: Professor Inmoo Lee
column12: was very friendly and knowledgeable. Final exam was very fair and we were allowed to bring cheat sheets.

column1: FMB686E East Asian Economic Development and Developing Countries / 3 ECTS / Recognized as MAN 550 International Course / Grading: 30 % participation and attendance
column2: 70% final exam / Interesting course in which we studied the ascent of Asian countries in the past decades. For this
column3: we read a well-written book by Michael Schuman (The Miracle). In each lesson
column4: the professor complemented the stories from the book with his own views. In the final exam we were asked to write an essay about a country of our choice. I’m not sure who will teach this course in the future as Professor Ji Soo Kim was about to retire when I was at KAIST.

column1: MGT 572 Financial Statement Analysis and Valuation / 6 ECTS / Recognized as AC 532 Financial Statement Analysis & Equity Valuation / Grading: Participation and attendance
column2: individual assignments
column3: final group project and presentation / This course was taught closely to the textbook ‘Equity Valuation and Analysis with eVal’ by Lundholm and Sloan. We were required to read the whole book and submit 7 individual assignments throughout the semester. The final project was challenging as we had to write a comprehensive analyst report including an industry analysis
column4: accounting analysis
column5: financial analysis
column6: forecasts and valuation. I would only take this course if you’re very interested in the subject.

column1: MGT593 Supply Chain Management / 6 ECTS / Recognized as OPM 550 International Course / Grading: Participation and attendance
column2: individual assignments
column3: team case presentation
column4: final group presentation / We covered 4 well-known supply chain cases (Obermeyer
column5: Barilla
column6: HP
column7: Nokia) for which we had to submit individual case reports or a team presentation. In addition
column8: there was midterm case (which was the most challenging case) and a final group presentation. All in all
column9: Professor Kun Soo Park provided a good introduction to supply chain management for beginners.

column1: MGT692 Service Management / 6 ECTS / Recognized as OPM 581 Service Operations Management / Grading: Participation and attendance
column2: individual assignments
column3: team case presentation
column4: quiz
column5: final group presentation / By far my favorite class during my exchange semester. This was less because of the subject but more because of Professor Yun Shin Lee. Her teaching style is very interactive with lots of discussions and in-class group exercises. Correspondingly
column6: the quiz was open-book and Excel-based. Take a course with Professor Yun Shin Lee
column7: you will enjoy it!";"I had wonderful time living in Seoul and getting to know the Korean people. With its buzzing districts and energetic people
column8: the vibe of Seoul is beyond all description. Korean people are one of the most hospitable
column9: mindful and warm-hearted people that I ever got to know. Even though many lack good English skills
column10: they are always polite and try to help you as best as they can. The people form the basis of a society which is future-oriented (Korea is one of the most innovative countries) while retaining traditional values.

column1: Regarding the studies
column2: don't expect too much from the courses at KAIST. Bear in mind that these are MBA courses which
column3: first
column4: are on a level such that non-business students can follow
column5: and second
column6: require some work. Nonetheless
column7: I could still acquire some valuable knowledge in some courses and got to know different styles of working. Also
column8: the location of the campus might not seem optimal
column9: but this is simultaneously a strength of this exchange program. As the majority of the exchange students lived together on a hill
column10: we grew together as group so that I've won many good friends from all over the world during this exchange. In conclusion
column11: I can only strongly encourage you to do your exchange at KAIST in Seoul!";https://www.service4mobility.com/mannheim/DispQuestionServlet?identifier=MANNHEI01&kz_call=A&sprache=de&org_id=72&q_set_nr=ERFAHRUNGSBERICHT&pk_table_name=bewerbung&pk_name=bew_id&inst_id_logo=413686&use_jsp=1&pk_id=209655&bew_id=209655;2024-04-21 23:09:04.048805
